It is probable that modern regulation of the current os the Danube by engineering works has had a tendency to prevent the formation of extensive ice fields. Yet even now the stream is frozen annually in Lower Hungary throughout several long stretches, which at the height of the frost can occasionally be crossed with carts or sleds. In Ba- varia, Austria, and Rumania, field ice does not form every winter. Yet it sometimes happens even at Vienna — most recently in Janu- ary, 1901 ——that the ice is strong enough to allow foot travellers a safe passage across the river.
